docs.title: Application Share Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the comprehensive documentation for Application Share - the enterprise-ready remote desktop platform that revolutionizes how you access and manage applications remotely.

docs.title: 🚀 What is Application Share?
docs.text: Application Share is a powerful web-based platform that allows you to run GUI applications on a server and display them in your browser, with advanced features like Hyprland-style tiling, multi-user collaboration, and enterprise-grade capabilities.

docs.title: Key Benefits
docs.text:
• 🌐 Web-Based Access - Access your applications from any modern browser
  • 🪟 Advanced Window Management - Tiled windows, snapping, and custom layouts
  • 👥 Multi-User Collaboration - Share sessions and work together
  • 📱 Mobile Support - Touch-friendly interface for mobile devices
  • 🔒 Enterprise Security - JWT authentication, encryption, and audit logging
  • 🐳 Production Ready - Docker, Kubernetes, and systemd support

docs.title: 🎯 Quick Start
docs.text:
Get up and running in minutes:

# Clone and deploy
git clone https://github.com/donskyblock/application-share.git
cd application-share
./deploy-all.sh
./start-all.sh

# Access at http://localhost:3000

docs.title: GitHub Pages Setup
docs.text: This guide explains how to set up GitHub Pages for the Application Share documentation.

docs.title: 1. Enable GitHub Pages
docs.text:
1. Go to your repository on GitHub
  2. Click Settings → Pages
  3. Under Source, select GitHub Actions
  4. Save the settings

docs.title: 2. Deploy Documentation
docs.text:
The documentation will automatically deploy when you push to the main branch thanks to the GitHub Actions workflow.

Manual deployment: 

# Install MkDocs
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Deploy to GitHub Pages
mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: 3. Access Your Documentation
docs.text:
Once deployed, your documentation will be available at: 

https://donskyblock.github.io/application-share

docs.title: 📁 Repository Structure
docs.text:
application-share/
├── docs/                    # Documentation source
│   ├── index.md            # Homepage
│   ├── getting-started/    # Getting started guides
│   ├── api/               # API documentation
│   └── ...
├── .github/
│   └── workflows/
│       └── docs.yml       # Auto-deployment workflow
├── mkdocs.yml             # MkDocs configuration
└── scripts/
    └── generate-docs.py   # Documentation generator

docs.title: 🔄 Automatic Updates
docs.text:
The documentation automatically updates when:

  • You push changes to the main branch
  • You merge a pull request
  • The GitHub Actions workflow runs

docs.title: 🛠️ Local Development
docs.text:
Preview locally: 

# Install dependencies
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

# Serve locally
mkdocs serve

# Open http://localhost:8000

Build documentation: 

# Generate docs from code
python scripts/generate-docs.py

# Build static site
mkdocs build

rm -rf site/

docs.text:

docs.title: API Reference

docs.title: 🔗 Base URL
docs.text: http://localhost:3000/api

docs.title: 🔐 Authentication
docs.text: All API endpoints require authentication using JWT tokens.

docs.title: Getting a Token
docs.text:
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/auth/login \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"username": "admin", "password": "your-password"}'

docs.title: Using the Token
docs.text:
Include the token in the Authorization header:

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_JWT_TOKEN" \
  http://localhost:3000/api/applications

    "is_admin": true

  -d '{"username": "admin", "password": "your_password"}'

# Start application
curl -X POST "http://localhost:3000/api/apps/start" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_JWT_TOKEN" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"app_name": "firefox"}'

# Get VNC info
curl -X GET "http://localhost:3000/api/vnc/info" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_JWT_TOKEN"

docs.title: Using JavaScript
docs.text:
// Login
const loginResponse = await fetch('/api/auth/login', {
  method: 'POST',
  headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
  body: JSON.stringify({ username: 'admin', password: 'password' })
});
const { access_token } = await loginResponse.json();

// Start application
const appResponse = await fetch('/api/apps/start', {
  method: 'POST',
  headers: { 
    'Authorization': `Bearer ${access_token}`,
    'Content-Type': 'application/json'
  },
  body: JSON.stringify({ app_name: 'firefox' })
});

app_data = {"app_name": "firefox"}

All API endpoints (except login and init-admin) require JWT authentication:

JWT tokens expire after 24 hours. Use the refresh endpoint to get a new token.

docs.title: Configuration

version: '3.8'
services:
  application-share:
    image: application-share:latest
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
      - "5900:5900"
      - "3389:3389"
    environment:
      - ADMIN_USERNAME=admin
      - ADMIN_PASSWORD=your-password
    volumes:
      - ./data:/app/data
      - ./logs:/app/logs

docker-compose -f docker-compose.prod.yml up -d

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get Application Share up and running in minutes!

docs.title: 🚀 Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Linux system with X11 support
  • Python 3.8+ and Node.js 16+
  • Docker (optional, for containerized deployment)

docs.title: Option 1: Complete Deployment (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/your-org/application-share.git
cd application-share

# Run the complete deployment script
chmod +x deploy-all.sh
./deploy-all.sh

# Start all services
./start-all.sh

docs.title: Option 2: Docker Deployment
docs.text:
# Clone and deploy with Docker
git clone https://github.com/your-org/application-share.git
cd application-share

# Deploy with Docker Compose
docker-compose up -d

# Or use the deployment script
./docker-deploy.sh

docs.title: Option 3: Manual Installation
docs.text:
# Install system dependencies
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y python3 python3-pip nodejs npm x11-utils xdotool imagemagick xvfb

# Install Python dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Install Node.js dependencies
cd client && npm install && npm run build && cd ..

# Configure environment
cp env.example .env
# Edit .env with your settings

# Start the application
python main.py

docs.title: 🌐 Access the Application
docs.text:
Once deployed, access Application Share at:

  • Web Interface: http://localhost:3000
  • VNC: localhost:5900
  • RDP: localhost:3389
  • Live Stream: http://localhost:3000/live

docs.title: 🔐 First Login
docs.text:
1. Open your browser to http://localhost:3000
  2. The admin account is automatically created
  3. Default credentials (check deployment output):
  4. Username: admin
  5. Password: (generated automatically)

docs.title: 1. Launch an Application
docs.text:
1. Click "Launch Application" on the dashboard
  2. Select an application (e.g., Firefox, VS Code)
  3. The application will open in a tiled window
  4. Interact with it using mouse and keyboard

docs.title: 2. Try Advanced Features
docs.text:
• File Transfer: Upload/download files
  • Audio Streaming: Enable audio for multimedia apps
  • Session Recording: Record your sessions
  • Window Management: Use tiling and snapping features

docs.title: 3. Mobile Access
docs.text:
• Open the web interface on your mobile device
  • Use touch controls for interaction
  • Access all features through the mobile interface

docs.title: 🔧 Quick Configuration
docs.text:
Edit .env file for basic configuration:

# Server settings
PORT=3000
NODE_ENV=production

# Admin credentials
ADMIN_USERNAME=admin
ADMIN_PASSWORD=your-secure-password

# VNC settings
ENABLE_VNC=true
VNC_PASSWORD=your-vnc-password

# RDP settings
ENABLE_RDP=true
RDP_PASSWORD=your-rdp-password

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Application won't start: 

# Check if X11 is running
echo $DISPLAY

# Start X11 virtual display
Xvfb :99 -screen 0 1920x1080x24 &
export DISPLAY=:99

Port already in use: 

# Check what's using the port
sudo netstat -tulpn | grep :3000

# Kill the process or change port in .env

Permission denied: 

# Make scripts executable
chmod +x *.sh

# Check file permissions
ls -la *.sh
